Description: The Department of Justice announced a settlement with KeySpan Corporation that requires KeySpan to pay $12 million for violating the antitrust laws by entering into an agreement restraining competition in the New York City electricity capacity market. The department said the financial derivative agreement likely resulted in a price increase for retail electricity suppliers and, in turn, an increase in electricity prices for consumers.

Description: Narragansett Electric Co. agreed to pay $5 million to reimburse costs of cleaning up hazardous waste in settlement of allegations a predecessor of the company had dumped truckloads of waste from coal gasification containing ferric ferrocyanide at a site in Attleboro.
National Grid agreed to pay $7 million in settlement of allegations it improperly charged a reconnection fee to thousands of customers, sometimes multiple times.
National Grid agreed to pay more than $1.5 million in credit to customers it was alleged were incorrectly charged a more expensive rate for natural gas.

National Grid agreed to pay approximately $2 million in settlement of allegations it violated wage an hour laws when its payroll problems during Hurricane Sandy resulted in failure to pay staff on time.
National Grid was ordered to pay $270,000 in fines for failing to pay wages correctly to workers and to pay in a timely manner after problems with a new pay system.

National Grid agreed to pay $1.2 million to customers in a further settlement over its response to the December 2010 storm, with allegations it created hardships for customers and dangerous conditions for public safety personnel.

National Grid agreed to pay more than one million dollars in training, charitable contributions, and service improvements, in settlement of allegations its errors resulted in delayed its response in restoring services after a storm.
The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities upheld an approximately $8 million fine against National Grid for failing to meet service quality requirements in 2006.
National Grid agreed to pay $4.8 million to settle allegations that it failed to properly pay its New York workers as required under state and federal law in the months after Hurricane Sandy.

Niagara Mohawk agreed to pay a  $3 million penalty, spend $3 million on environmental projects and convey 2,500 acres of land as part of a settlement involving the reduction of air pollution caused by power plants.

Description: National Grid agreed to pay $6 million to resolve allegations it knowingly provided false reports to the Long Island Power Authority on the amount of electricity was being delivered, but not billed for.

The New York State Public Service Commission determined that a proposed settlement of a penalty action against National Grid's upstate business, under which National Grid would set aside $500,000 for the benefit of customers relating to gas safety, would be acceptable, with modifications.

The New York State Public Service Commission approved a proposal that would resolve a possible penalty action against National Grid's natural gas business on Long Island for a gas incident that occurred on February 11, 2015, causing severe injury to two people.
National Grid's New York City and Long island gas businesses had repeated violations of gas safety regulations that are designed to ensure that underground gas pipelines are protected from corrosion.

Description: The DPU ordered three utilities to pay a total of $24.8 million in penalties after finding deficiencies in their responses to Tropical Storm Irene and the October 2011 snowstorm.
Info Source: Department of Public Utilities Imposes $24.8 Million in Penalties for Utilities' 2011 Storm Responses, Targeted News Service, December 11, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities issued Colonial Gas Co. d/b/a National Grid a $1.25 million civil penalty for safety violations.
Info Source: Mass. regulator fines National Grid utility $1.25M for gas line safety violations, SNL Gas Week, January 4, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: The Department of Public Utilities issued an Order that imposed a $750,000 penalty on National Grid for inadequate storm preparation and power restoration efforts related to an October 29, 2017 windstorm that affected over 330,000 National Grid electric customers in 166 communities.
